text: you should have a .env - at the same level as package.json usually known as the "application root" level

elements.text: you should have a .env - at the same level as package.json usually known as the "application root" level

text:
within that .env you should have
```CLIENT_ID=
CLIENT_SECRET=```

elements.text: within that .env you should have

text: and behind those you should use the CLIENT_ID and CLIENT_SECRET you find from the spotify developer section.

elements.text: and behind those you should use the CLIENT_ID and CLIENT_SECRET you find from the spotify developer section.

text:
i.e. say what you see on the web page of spotify is abcde as client_id and edcba as client_secret your .env should look like this:
```CLIENT_ID=abcde
CLIENT_SECRET=edcba```

text: I am not quite sure if I understand your question -> you don't want a limit on the number of artists fetched?

elements.text: I am not quite sure if I understand your question -> you don't want a limit on the number of artists fetched?

text: I think you can increase the limit by providing a custom options object to the function as an argument.

elements.text: I think you can increase the limit by providing a custom options object to the function as an argument.

text: then you could say - limit: 100000

elements.text: then you could say - limit: 100000

text: or something like this.

elements.text: or something like this.

elements.text: 20 objects are returned from console.log-ing data.body

elements.text: ah, you mean that it concatenates the logs in the response?

text:
tldr: one hacky way to do it:
```console.log(JSON.stringify(myObject, null, 4));```

elements.text: tldr: one hacky way to do it:

text:
there's also:
```console.dir(myObject, { depth: null }); ```

text:
so for your case this should work.
```console.dir(data, { depth: null })```
